name: git-repo-window-colors
description: Customize the color of each window's activityBar, titleBar, tabs, and status bar based on the git repository name and branch.

windowColors.repoConfigurationList.markdownDescription:
Entries in this list are optional. Each entry in the ordered list has the form `<repo-qualifier>[/<default-branch>]:<primary-color>[/<branch-color>]` (i.e. `myrepo:blue` or `myrepo/main:blue/green`).  The `repo-qualifier` is required. The repository qualifier is a simple string. If this string is found in the repository URL as given by `git config --get remote.origin.url`, then a match is made.  The first match found  will be used.  The `primary-color` is the color associated with the repository.  This color will be used to color the window title bar and activity bar (when not using branch colors).

The `default-branch` is optional and represents the default GitHub branch for the repository. If the `default-branch` is specified then the activity bar will be shown in a different color when you are not working on the default branch. This other color is specified either by the `branch-color` setting, if provided, or automatically determined using the `#windowColors.automaticBranchIndicatorColorKnob#` setting. You can invert the branch coloring logic using `#windowColors.invertBranchColorLogic#`

Colors can be specified in any form recognized by the Javascript Color class.  See: [Colors Tutorial](https://www.w3schools.com/colors/default.asp).

You can use whitespace to make the list more readable.  All whitespace will be stripped for processing.

Format Reference: `<repo-qualifier>[/<default-branch>]:<primary-color>[/<branch-color>]`

windowColors.removeManagedColors.description: When no rules match, remove any colors that were set by this extension.  This is useful if you want to use the default colors for a repo that is not in the list. If this is unchecked, then you will need to remove any managed colors manually.

windowColors.invertBranchColorLogic.description: Use the branch color to indicate when you are working in the default branch.  This is only used when a default branch is specified for the repo and does not apply to the branch colors defined in `#windowColors.branchConfigurationList#`

windowColors.branchConfigurationList.markdownDescription:
Each entry in the ordered list has the form `<branch-pattern>:<branch-color>` (i.e. `feature-.*:blue` or 'bug-.*:red' or 'mybranch').  If a branch pattern in this table is matched against the current working branch, then this setting will override any branch coloring from the repo configuration list above.  The first match found is used. Branches defined in this list are not tied to a repo, meaning that if you are working on any repo whos working branch matches the pattern the coloring will be applied.

Format Reference: `<branch-pattern>:<branch-color>`

windowColors.colorInactiveTitlebar.description: Check to apply color changes to the inactive window title bar.

windowColors.colorEditorTabs.description: Check to apply color changes to editor tabs (and sidebar title area).

windowColors.colorStatusBar.description: Check to apply color changes to editor tabs (and sidebar title area).

windowColors.activityBarColorKnob.description: Lighten or darken the non-title bar colors by this factor between -10 and 10. A value of zero is no difference.

windowColors.applyBranchColorToTabsAndSt.description: In addition to the Activity Bar, apply the branch color to the editor tabs and status bar

windowColors.automaticBranchIndicatorCol.description: When repository settings does not spcify a branch color, use this knob to control the hue rotation of the repository color to automatically set the branch color.  Smaller values will be similar to the repository color.  A value of 180 is the 'opposite' of the repository color on the color wheel.

windowColors.showBranchColumns.description: Show the Default Branch and Branch Color columns in the Repository Rules table. When unchecked, these branch-related columns are hidden to provide a more compact view.

windowColors.showStatusIconWhenNoRuleMat.description: When checked, the status bar icon is only shown when no rule matches the current repository. When unchecked, the status bar icon is always shown when the workspace is a git repository. The icon is never shown when the workspace is not a git repository.

windowColors.askToColorizeRepoWhenOpened.description: When enabled, the extension will ask if you'd like to colorize a repository when opening a workspace folder on a repository that doesn't match any existing rules.
